----Original Message-----
>From: Ilja Preu=DF [mailto:ilja.preuss@...]
>=
Sent: Wednesday, September 11, 2002 8:51 AM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com

ject: Re: RE: [junit] [TEST] JTest v4.5 and what is says about JUnit
>
>
>>=
You are free to uninstall Jtest and take a chance on shipping 
>untested, s=
ub-optimal code and you are free to keep Jtest 
>installed and have some of=
 the squeakiest clean code on the 
>planet. I know which I'm gonna do.
>
>T=
here is of course at least a third option: uninstall JTest 
>and ship teste=
d, optimal code nevertheless... ;-)

While unit tests are a Very Good Thing=
(tm) they are not 100% of the testing that should be performed on a body of=
 code. So, I know that I will be using a combination of Jtest and Junit for=
 a long time to come. If you write optimal code without the need for automa=
ted testing tools, then I salute you! :-)


>> I would actually interpret t=
hese exceptions as an indication 
>of some extra guard conditions and more =
defensive programming 
>needed within the tested code. If a piece of called=
 code 
>cannot handle unexpected inputs, then the fault lies with the 
>cod=
e and not the inputs. :-)
>
>I disagree. If the input violates a preconditi=
on, the fault 
>lies with the input, by definition.

I wholeheartedly disag=
ree with you. It makes no difference what your "contract" is between a piec=
e of software and it's callers, if the software doesn't check it's own inpu=
ts then it is at fault.

Now, some pieces of functionality may not be criti=
cal enough to code guard conditions upon, an example might be getters and s=
etters, or some simple string or mathematics functions. But there are going=
 to be some where the functionality is going to be be of a life-threatening=
 level and I know that I'd want a VERY robust guard condition on that code.=
 An example of such a critical piece of code might be for Radiation Treatme=
nt units. I don't care how many documents you have that say that the output=
 requested will never be above n units of radiation, I'm gonna build a guar=
d condition into my code to make certain that it could never happen.


>Reg=
ards, Ilja

Simon
